subsection.title: Overview
subsection.p: The limit of a sequence describes its end behavior. A sequence can have similar end behavior as any other function. (Recall .) Some sequences seemed to level off to a single value, approaching a horizontal asymptote. Other sequences grow without bound, either rising to +\infty or falling to -\infty. Additionally, sequences might approach a repeating pattern or have no pattern at all. In this section, we focus on describing the limiting behavior of sequences that level off to a single limiting value or grow without bound.

The objectives for this section are as follows. We will focus on what it means for a sequence to have a limit. Then we will learn how to determine the limiting values for sequences defined explicitly using limit arithmetic. Additionally, we will also learn about limits of sequences defined recursively in terms of fixed points of the projection function .

subsection.title: What Is A Limit?
subsection.p: We want to say that a sequence has a limit if the plot of the sequence values levels off to a single value. The limit will be that value to which the sequence is converging. The numerical interpretation of this perspective is that if you looked at a table of values for the sequence, the values of the sequence needs to have its values get closer and closer to some limiting value. In a decimal representation, more and more of the digits need to stop changing the further you go down in the sequence.
We start with a few examples to build our intuition.

example.p: The table below represent the values for a sequence defined explicitly as \displaystyle x_n = \frac{3+2^n}{1+3 \cdot 2^n}, shown with up to 12 decimal places. A plot of the sequence is also shown.

The plot for the sequence shows that the sequence appears to be leveling off. Looking at the table, we see that more and more of the digits are converging to a 3. If this pattern is real and continues, the limiting value would be the repeating decimal 0.3333\ldots which is the rational number \frac{1}{3}. We would say that this sequence has a limit of \frac{1}{3}. We write either x_n \to \frac{1}{3} or \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = \frac{1}{3}.
Another sequence, defined explicitly by the formula u_n = 1+\frac{1}{2}\cdot(-1+\frac{1}{2^n})^n, is similarly illustrated by a table and figure.

Notice that for this sequence, the graph appears to level off to two different values. However, this is because the sequence is actually approaching two alternating values. This is an example of approaching a repeating pattern rather than a value, most easily seen in the table. As we look further down the table, the odd index values correspond to a sequence value that is getting closer to 0.5 while the even index values correspond to a sequence value that is getting closer to 1.5. This sequence does not have a limit because the sequence is not approaching a single value. We say \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n does not exist.

Another third sequence, defined by the nonlinear recursive formula z_{n+1} = 2.7 z_n - 0.7 z_n^2 with initial value z_0 = 1 does not have a convenient explicit formula. However, using a computer to generate approximate values and then graph the sequence, we can explore whether this sequence appears to have a limit.

Graphically, you should see that the plot shows the sequence values are leveling off to a single value. However, the graph also shows that the values are alternately above and below that limit. We look in the table to determine the limiting value, but it is not obvious from the table what the limiting value should be. Because the values are alternately above and then below whatever the limit should be, we can conclude that the limit must be between the last two values listed. The limit is approximately 2.428 but we do not know the next decimal place without computing more values in the sequence. With additional computation (not shown), we find z_{39} = 2.42857109636261 and z_{40} = 2.42857166111753 so that our approximation for the limit (a value between z_{39} and z_{40}) can be estimated as close to 2.428571. To find a better approximation would require more computation.

subsection.p: With these examples, we can introduce the mathematical definition for the limit of a sequence. The idea of a limit x_n \to L is that the value of the sequence x_n approximates the value of L closer and closer as n increases. This is made precise by showing that the error of approximation, |x_n - L|, will eventually become smaller than any desired accuracy of approximation.

statement.p:
A sequence x has a limit L (where L is a real number), and we write \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = L \quad \text{or} \quad x_n \to L, if for any desired accuracy of approximation \epsilon \gt 0, the error of approximation is eventually |x_n - L| \lt \epsilon. This means that for every \epsilon \gt 0, there is a threshold index N so that |x_n-L| \lt \epsilon whenever n \gt N.
\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = L sequence x_n has limit L
x_n \to L sequence x_n has limit L

subsection.p: In most cases, verifying the definition directly will be too challenging. However, for sequences defined by sufficiently simple explicit formulas, we can determine how far down the table we need to go to reach a desired accuracy.

example.p: Consider the sequence \displaystyle x_n = \frac{n}{2n+1}, for n=0,1,2,\ldots. Using the following simple Sage script, we can generate a plot and table quickly.

sage.input:
# What range of index values to plot lastIndex = 100 # How many of the final values in the calculation to show? showLast = 10
# Calculate the table for plotting data = [] for n in range(lastIndex+1): xn = n/(2*n+1) data.append( (n,xn) ) graph = list_plot(data, frame=True, axes_labels=["n", "x_n"]) show(graph)
# Display a portion of the table for n in range(lastIndex-showLast,lastIndex+1): # data is a list of points, so data[n] = (n,xn) # Format %d means as integer, \t means tab # and %10.8f means 8 decimal places in 10 available print "%d\t%10.8f" % data[n]

example.p: It appears that the sequence is leveling out to a value near 0.5. However, at index n=100, the value is at approximately x_{100} \approx 0.49751244 (8 decimal places). If the limit really is x_n \to 0.5, then the error of approximation for n=100 is |x_{100}-0.5| \approx 0.00248756. We need to ensure that the error continues to go down. At index n=1000 (by modifying the script and running again), we have x_{1000} \approx 0.49975012 with an error of approximation |x_{1000}-0.5| \approx 0.00024988.

From our graph, we have seen that (n,x_n) is increasing and concave down. Given any desired error of approximation \epsilon \gt 0, we can use our inverse function to see exactly when the sequence rises above x_n \gt \frac{1}{2}-\epsilon. For example, with \epsilon = 0.001, we want to find when x_n \gt 0.5-0.001=0.499. We find f^{-1}(0.499) = \frac{0.499}{1-2(0.499)} =249.5. The sequence, which requires integer index values, will therefore be above x_n \gt 0.499 for n \ge 250. We can verify this numerically by running the script to show a table for index values surrounding n=250.

The inverse function, \displaystyle f^{-1}(x)=\frac{x}{1-2x}, is undefined for x=\frac{1}{2}. For values x \gt \frac{1}{2}, we will have negative values for n, f^{-1}(x) \lt 0. The sequence therefore will never reach or surpass the value x=\frac{1}{2}. But we will be able to identify when the function rises above every value below x=\frac{1}{2}. This is how we know that \lim_{n \to \infty}x_n = \frac{1}{2}.

subsection.title: Limits from Explicit Formulas
subsection.p: Using a table of values to find a limit only allows us to estimate its value. In addition, it is not clear from a table whether the pattern that this estimation is based on will continue or change. So it would be helpful to have some rules for finding limits based on the formula rather than numerical patterns.

In order to compute limits of sequences, we first need to understand that some sequences grow without bound, which is written x_n \to \infty when the sequence grows in a positive direction or x_n \to -\infty when the sequence grows in a negative direction. Arithmetic sequences with increments c \ne 0 (recall ) must either steadily increase (c \gt 0) or steadily decrease (c \lt 0). The special case that c=0 is somewhat boring, as this corresponds to a constant sequence so that the limit is just the constant value.

statement.p:
An arithmetic sequence with explicit formula x_n = a + c \cdot n (for constants a and c) has unbounded growth when c \ne 0. The corresponding limit statements are
\lim_{n \to \infty} (a+c n) = +\infty \quad & (c \gt 0) \lim_{n \to \infty} (a+c n) = -\infty \quad & (c \lt 0) \lim_{n \to \infty} (a) = a \quad & (c = 0)

subsection.p: Geometric sequences are a little more complicated, depending on the ratio \rho (recall ) and the initial value. Repeated multiplication by a number whose magnitude is larger than 1 makes the resulting magnitude increase without bound. Repeated multiplication by a number whose magnitude is smaller than 1 makes the resulting magnitude converge to 0. If the ratio is negative, then the sign of the sequence values will alternate between positive and negative. This is summarized by another theorem.

statement.p:
A geometric sequence with explicit formula x_n = a \cdot \rho^n and ratio \rho is unbounded when |\rho| \gt 1, meaning that |x_n| \to +\infty. If \rho \le -1, x_n alternates sign and the limit does not exist. If \rho \gt 1, then the limit depends on the sign of a:
\lim_{n \to \infty} a \cdot \rho^n = +\infty, \quad & (a \gt 0), \lim_{n \to \infty} a \cdot \rho^n = -\infty, \quad & (a \lt 0).
If |\rho| \lt 1 (i.e., -1 \lt \rho \lt 1), then \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} a \cdot \rho^n = 0.
Find the appropriate limits of the following sequences.

li.p: The sequence x_n = 3-4n is recognized as the explicit formula of an arithmetic sequence with increment c=-4. Since this is a negative increment, the sequence decreases without bound. So we write \lim_{n \to \infty} 3-4n = -\infty.
The sequence x_n = 100+0.02n is arithmetic with increment c=0.02. Since the increment is positive, the sequence increases without bound and we write \lim_{n \to \infty} 100+0.02n = +\infty.

The sequence x_n=-3 \cdot 1.05^n is a geometric sequence with ratio \rho=1.05. Because \rho \gt 1, the sequence grows without bound. Furthermore, because the terms are all negative, we have a limit \lim_{n \to \infty} -3 \cdot 1.05^n = -\infty.

The sequence x_n = 100 \cdot (-0.75)^n is a geometric sequence with ratio \rho=-0.75. Because the ratio is negative, the signs of the terms alternate between positive and negative. However, since |\rho|= 0.75 \lt 1, the magnitude of the terms converges to zero so that \lim_{n \to \infty} 100 \cdot (-0.75)^n = 0.

The sequence x_n = 5 \cdot (-1.5)^n has a negative ratio \rho=-1.5. Since |\rho| \gt 1, the terms have alternating signs but grow in magnitude. Consequently, \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} 5 \cdot (-1.5)^n does not exist.

subsection.p: Once we know how to identify when sequences have unbounded terms, we can use that information to find limits of related sequences. We can think of this as the arithmetic of infinity. Infinities can add and multiply but should never be subtracted or divided from one another. The most important principle to remember is that infinities should never cancel one another. Cases where the formula looks like infinities might cancel are called indeterminate. This means that the actual value can not be determined without further analysis. A ratio of terms becoming infinitely small, 0/0, is also indeterminate.

statement.p: Suppose unbounded sequences are combined using arithmetic operations. Then the following arithmetic relating to limits will be valid.

subsection.p: The previous theorem was stated somewhat imprecisely in order to convey the idea of arithmetic of infinities without being bogged down by formal notation relating to limits. Each statement really is about a limit.

As an example, the arithmetic on infinity +\infty + +\infty = +\infty should more properly be stated as follows. Suppose that there are two sequences x_n and y_n such that x_n \to +\infty and y_n \to +\infty. The sequence defined by u_n = x_n + y_n has limit \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n + y_n = +\infty.

The shorthand notation of performing arithmetic with infinity allows this to be simplified as writing \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n + y_n = +\infty + +\infty = +\infty. The intermediate step +\infty + +\infty is not truly arithmetic, but points out that x_n \to +\infty and y_n \to +\infty, and since those sequences were added, the final limit is also +\infty. As long as the arithmetic involves no cancelation of infinities, it will result in a correct statement.
To deal with indeterminate forms, we usually need to try to rewrite the formula in a new way so that the cancellation does not apply.

statement.p: Determine the following limits, if possible.

li.p: The sequence x_n = 3 + \frac{5}{2^n} is the sum of terms 3 and \frac{5}{2^n}. The constant sequence has a limit 3 \to 3 (since it never changes). The geometric sequence \frac{5}{2^n} = 5 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^n has a ratio |\rho| \lt 1 so that \frac{5}{2^n} \to 0. The form of the limit (using the terms) is \lim_{n \to \infty} 3 + \frac{5}{2^n} = 3 + 0, and since this does not involve any cancelation of infinities, will give the correct limit, \lim_{n \to \infty} 3+\frac{5}{2^n} = 3+0 = 3.
The sequence \displaystyle u_n = \frac{n^2-3n}{5n-1} is a quotient of terms n^2-3n and 5n-1. To find the limit, we explore the terms individually first.

Because n^2 = n \cdot n, we know n^2 \to +\infty \cdot +\infty = +\infty. Similarly, the arithmetic sequence 3n \to +\infty. However, the difference n^2 - 3n would have a limit of the form +\infty - \infty, which is a cancellation of infinities. As written, n^2-3n is an indeterminate form. Our strategy will be to rewrite this as a product, and the best practice is to factor out (divide out) the greatest power of n, n^2-3n = n^2(\frac{n^2}{n^2} - \frac{3n}{n^2}) = n^2 (1 - \frac{3}{n}). From this, we find \frac{3}{n} \to \frac{3}{+\infty} = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad 1-\frac{3}{n} \to 1-0 = 1. Since we already know n^2 \to +\infty, we have the limit of the numerator \lim_{n \to \infty} n^2-3n = \lim_{n \to \infty} n^2(1-\frac{3}{n}) = +\infty \cdot 1 = +\infty.

The term in the denominator 5n-1 is an arithmetic sequence (linear function) with increment (slope) c=5. We know \lim_{n \to \infty} 5n-1 = +\infty. Unfortunately, that means our limit form as a quotient is itself an indeterminate form, \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^2-3n}{5n-1} = \frac{+\infty}{+\infty}. We can not cancel infinities, so we must rewrite our formula.

For this example, I worked out the numerator separately to make a point about that term itself being an indeterminate form. In practice, our strategy will be to apply that factoring principle to the entire formula at one step. This is illustrated below.

The sequence \displaystyle w_n = \frac{1+2^n}{3+5^n}, by quick inspection, involves the geometric sequences 2^n and 5^n, both of which grow exponentially so that w_n \to \frac{+\infty}{+\infty}. This indeterminate form involves canceling infinities, so we must rewrite the formula. Following the method of the previous example, we factor out the dominant term, in this case the geometrically growing powers.
\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1+2^n}{3+5^n} & = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2^n(\frac{1}{2^n} + \frac{2^n}{2^n})}{5^n(\frac{3}{5^n}+\frac{5^n}{5^n})} & = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2^n(\frac{1}{2^n}+1)}{5^n(\frac{3}{5^n}+1)}
This is still indeterminate form \frac{+\infty}{+\infty}, so we rewrite \displaystyle \frac{2^n}{5^n} = ({\textstyle \frac{2}{5}})^n, which is a geometric sequence with ratio \rho=\frac{2}{5} satisfying |\rho| \lt 1.
\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1+2^n}{3+5^n} & = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2^n(\frac{1}{2^n}+1)}{5^n(\frac{3}{5^n}+1)} & = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{(\frac{2}{5})^n(\frac{1}{2^n}+1)}{\frac{3}{5^n}+1} & = \frac{0 \cdot (0+1)}{0+1} = \frac{0}{1} = 0

subsection.title: Sequence Limits and Fixed Points
subsection.p: When a sequence x is defined recursively by a projection function f, x_{n+1} = f(x_n), we often do not have explicit formulas for the sequence values. That means our strategies involving formulas don't apply to such sequences. However, we can often find the limiting value by finding what are called the fixed points of the projection function.

statement.p: A fixed point for a function f is a solution to the equation f(x) = x.

subsection.p: The idea of a fixed point is a value so that the input and output are the same values. In the context of recursive sequences, x_{n+1}=f(x_n), if x_n is at the value of a fixed point, then x_{n+1}=f(x_n)=x_n. The value of the sequence will repeat forever. A fixed point is also called a stationary point or an equilibrium.

statement.p:
Find the fixed point(s) of the each of the projection functions. Then see what happens to a recursive sequence x_{n+1}=f(x_n) with an initial value close to the fixed point.
f(x)=1.4x-5
f(x)=0.8x+3
f(x)=1.1x-0.02x^2

solution.p: Fixed points are found by solving the equation x=f(x). Do not solve f(x)=0! We are solve the equation where the input to the function x equals the output of the function f(x).

li.p:
For f(x)=1.4x-5, the fixed point equation is x=1.4x-5.
x=1.4x-5 x-1.4x=-5 -0.4x=-5 x=\frac{-5}{-0.4}=12.5
That is, f(12.5) = 1.4(12.5)-5 = 17.5-5=12.5 (output equals input). The fixed pont is x^*=12.5. (The notation x^* is to indicate a special value of x. The asterisk is just a decoration.)

A sequence defined by the projection function with initial value x_0=x^*=12.5 will have a constant value, or steady state.
x_0 &= x^* = 12.5 x_1 &= f(x^*) = x^* = 12.5 &\vdots x_n &= x^* = 12.5
However, if we start at a value close to the fixed point, say x_0=12.4, then the sequence is not constant.
x_0 &= 12.4 x_1 &= f(12.4) = 1.4(12.4)-5 = 12.36 x_2 &= f(12.36) = 1.4(12.36)-5 = 12.304 x_3 &= f(12.304) = 1.4(12.304)-5 = 12.2256
We can see that the sequence is moving away from the fixed point.

For f(x)=0.8x+3, the fixed point equation is x=0.8x+3.
x=0.8x+3 0.2x=3 x=\frac{3}{0.2}=15
The fixed point is x^*=15 because f(15) = 0.8(15)+3 = 12+3=15 (output equals input).

A sequence defined by the projection function with initial value x_0=x^*=15 will have a constant value, or steady state.
x_0 &= x^* = 15 x_1 &= f(x^*) = x^* = 15 &\vdots x_n &= x^* = 15
However, if we start at a value close to the fixed point, say x_0=14, then the sequence is not constant.
x_0 &= 14 x_1 &= f(14) = 0.8(14)+3 = 14.2 x_2 &= f(14.2) = 0.8(14.2)+3 = 14.36 x_3 &= f(14.36) = 0.8(14.36)+3 = 14.488
We can see that this sequence is moving toward the fixed point.

For f(x)=1.1x-0.02x^2, the fixed point equation is x=1.1x-0.02x^2.
x=1.1x-0.02x^2 0=0.1x-0.02x^2 x(0.1-0.02x)=0 x=0 \quad \text{or} \quad x=\frac{0.1}{0.02}=5
This projection function has two fixed points, x^*=0 and x^\dagger=5.

A sequence defined by the projection function with initial value x_0=x^*=0 will have the constant value x_n=0. However, if the initial value is x_0=x^\dagger=5, then the sequence will have the constant value x_n=5. Now, if we start at a value close to x^*, say x_0=0.2, then the sequence is not constant.
x_0 &= 0.2 x_1 &= f(0.2) = 1.1(0.2)-0.02(0.2)^2 = 0.2192 x_2 &= f(0.2192) = 1.1(0.2192)-0.02(0.2192)^2 \approx 0.24015903
The sequence moves away from x^*. On the other hand, if we start near x^\dagger, say x=4.8, the sequence actually moves closer to x^\dagger.
x_0 &= 4.8 x_1 &= f(4.8) = 1.1(4.8)-0.02(4.8)^2 = 4.8192 x_2 &= f(0.2192) = 1.1(4.8192)-0.02(4.8192)^2 \approx 4.83662623

subsection.p: The reason that we search for fixed points is that if we know there is a limit for a recursively defined sequence, the limit will usually be a fixed point of the projection function.

statement.p: If a sequence is defined recursively with a continuous projection function f, x_{n+1}=f(x_n), and x_n has a limit, then the limit must be a fixed point of f.

subsection.p: Note some things that this theorem does not guarantee. First, just because a function has a fixed point does not mean that it will be a limit. (The sequence might not have a limit.) Second, the projection function needs to be continuous. If a function is not continuous, then it is possible to have a limit that is not a fixed point. Fortunately, functions defined by simple algebraic formulas will be continuous everywhere they are defined. For any continuous projection functions, the only limits will be fixed points.

In practice, we first observe that a sequence defined recursively has a limit (perhaps through a graph or a table) but can not determine the value of the limit. If we find all of the fixed points for the projection function, then we can determine which of those is the appropriate limit. The limit may depend on the initial value of the sequence, so we compare approximate values from the table with the approximate (decimal) values of the fixed points.

statement.p: We in an example above that the sequence defined recursively by z_{n+1} = 2.7 z_n-0.7z_n^2 and initial value z_0 = 1, and that the approximate value of the limit was 2.428. What is the exact value of the limit?

solution.p: The projection function f : z_n \mapsto z_{n+1}=2.7z_n - 0.7z_n^2 is defined by the formula f(x) = 2.7x-0.7x^2. This function involves simple algebra and is defined everywhere. Therefore, the projection function f is continuous and the limit must be a fixed point.

subsection.p: Fixed points are also useful in finding the explicit formula for sequences defined by linear projection functions. Suppose a sequence is defined recursively by the equation x_{n+1} = \alpha x_n + c. When c=0, we have a geometric sequence. When \alpha = 1 we have an arithmetic sequence. The projection function f:x_n \mapsto x_{n+1} is defined by the formula f(x) = \alpha x + c. The fixed point x^* is the solution to \alpha x + c = x \qquad \Leftrightarrow \qquad x^* = \frac{c}{1-\alpha}, defined only for \alpha \ne 1.

The linear projection function can be rewritten in terms of the fixed point using slope \alpha and point (x^*,x^*) as f(x) = x^* + \alpha(x-x^*). This means that the recurrence relation can be written x_{n+1} = x^* + \alpha(x_n-x^*) \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad x_{n+1}-x^* = \alpha(x_n-x^*). Consequently, x_n-x^* is a geometric sequence. This allows us to find an explicit formula for x_n.

theorem.title: Explicit Formula for Linear Recursive Sequences

statement.p: Suppose x_n is defined recursively by the equation x_{n+1} = \alpha x + c with \alpha \ne 1. Then x_n is defined explicitly by a shifted geometric sequence x_n = x^* + (x_0-x^*) \cdot \alpha^n = x^* + (x_1 -x^*) \cdot \alpha^{n-1}, where \displaystyle x^* = \frac{c}{1-\alpha} is the fixed point.

subsection.p: This theorem implies that a sequence defined recursively by a linear projection function will converge to the fixed point when the slope has magnitude less than 1. Immediate consequences of theorems are called corollaries.

statement.p: A sequence defined recursively by x_{n+1} = \alpha x_n + c with |\alpha| \lt 1 will converge to the fixed point \displaystyle x^* = \frac{c}{1-\alpha}, independent of the initial value.
Find the explicit formula for a sequence defined by the recursive equation x_{n+1} = 1.05 x_n - 20 and initial value x_0=300.

solution.p:
Start by finding the fixed point, solving the equation x=1.05x - 20.
x=1.05x-20 -0.05x = -20 x=400
Using the fixed point x^*=400 and the growth factor \alpha=1.05, we can write down the explicit formula,
x_n &= x^* + (x_0-x^*)\alpha^n &= 400+(300-400)1.05^n &= 400-100 \cdot 1.05^n

subsection.p: Now that we have a method for finding the explicit formula for a sequence with a linear projection function, we can apply that formula to analyze applied models.

statement.p: Suppose a patient begins taking 500 of a drug every four hours. However, the body metabolizes 60 of the drug in the body every four hours. Find a formula for the amount of drug in the body immediately after each dose and then determine the limiting value.

solution.p: The body starts with no drug. Immediately after the first dose, there are 500. Four hours later, 60 has been removed and then another dose is added in. If we let D_n be the sequence of drug mass in the body as a function of the number of doses n, then this is modeled recursively by the equation D_{n+1} = D_n - 0.6 D_n + 500, with initial value D_1 = 500.

This model has a linear projection function f(x) = 0.4x+500 and corresponding fixed point 0.4x+500=x \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad x=\frac{500}{0.6} = \frac{2500}{3}. The explicit formula, using , is given by D_n = \frac{2500}{3} + (500 - \frac{2500}{3}) \cdot 0.4^{n-1} = \frac{2500}{3} - \frac{1000}{3} \cdot 0.4^{n-1}. Because the slope of the projection function \alpha = 0.4 has magnitude less than 1, the limiting value is the fixed point x^* = \frac{2500}{3} \approx 833.33. Thus, if the patient continues to take the drug, the amount in the body immediately after each dose will be approximately 833.33. (Immediately before the dose, it must have been approximately 333.33.)

ul.li: A sequence has a limit, x_n \to L, if the values of the sequence get closer and closer to the value of L. The line x=L will be a horizontal asymptote of the graph (n,x_n).

The formal definition of a sequence limit x_n \to L, also written \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = L, is that for any desired error of approximation \epsilon \gt 0, there is an index threshold N so that |x_n - L| \lt \epsilon whenever n \gt N. (See )

Arithmetic sequences with non-zero increments are unbounded. Geometric sequences are unbounded when the ratio has magnitude greater than 1 and converge to zero when the ratio has magnitude less than 1.

li.p:
Sequence limits obey the standard rules of arithmetic, including for infinite limits, with the exception that any formula that would cancel infinity are indeterminate. (See ) Indeterminate means the limit can not be determined from simple arithmetic but requires rewriting in another form.
\infty-\infty: rewrite by factoring out dominant term
\displaystyle \frac{\infty}{\infty}: factor out dominant term in numerator and denominator, look to simplify
\displaystyle \frac{0}{0}: try to factor and simplify
\displaystyle 0 \cdot \infty: use negative powers to rewrite as fraction, then treat as \frac{0}{0} or \frac{\infty}{\infty}
Look for terms in the limit that vanish: \displaystyle \frac{1}{\infty}=0.
Given a function f, a fixed point of f solves the fixed point equation x=f(x). (See )
Sequences defined recursively using a continuous projection function f can only have limits that are fixed points of f. (See )

introduction.p: Use a computer-generated table to approximate the limit of the following sequences to at least four decimal places. If the limit does not exists, state why.

statement.p: \displaystyle x_{n+1} = \frac{x_n}{5} + \frac{2}{x_n} with x_0 = 2.
\displaystyle x_{n+1} = \frac{x_n}{5} - \frac{2}{x_n} with x_0 = 2.
\displaystyle x_{n+1} = 5x_n e^{-x_n} with x_0 = 0.5.

For each of the following sequences, explore the definition of a limit.

statement.p: The sequence x_n = \frac{1}{2n+1} has a limit x_n \to 0. For \epsilon = 0.01, find N so that |x_n-0| \lt \epsilon for n \gt N.

The sequence x_n = \left(-\frac{2}{3}\right)^n has a limit x_n \to 0. For \epsilon = 0.01, find N so that |x_n-0| \lt \epsilon for n \gt N.

introduction.p: Find an explicit formula for each sequence. Then determine the limit of the sequence.

statement.p: When a patient starts taking a drug, there is no drug in the blood. The prescription is to take 250 every six hours. Then, during the six hours between doses, the body metabolizes 20 of whatever drug is in the body.

Find a recursive formula using a linear projection function for the sequence of drug levels with an index counting the total number of doses. Clearly state the initial value. Find an explicit formula for the sequence and determine the limit. Is there a steady state amount of drug in the body?

A pond has been polluted by a stream. The pond holds 12,000 gallons of water and the stream replaces 900 gallons per day. The stream has been carrying the chemical pollutant at a concentration of 0.4 and now the pond has that same pollution level. With stream cleanup, the chemical pollutant in the stream has just been reduced to a concentration of 0.1.

Find a recursive formula using a linear projection function for the sequence of pollutant levels (total mass) in the pond with an index counting the number of days since the cleanup occurred. Clearly state the initial value. Find an explicit formula for the sequence and determine the limit. On what day will the total amount of pollutant in the pond be reduced to half of the pollution level prior to cleanup? Is there a steady state amount of pollutant in the pond?
